Why can't society just agree with the Bible's morals, even if many don't think of it as proof of God?

 
 Mostly because they aren't the Bible's morals. Which isn't to say that the morality expressed in the Bible isn't solid. But the idea that you should do something just because the Bible says so is only going to lead you into trouble. Civilized behavior should be based on rational reasoning, not faith. The morality in the Bible, like all morality which has stood the test of time, is based on the simple belief that helping people is good and hurting people is bad. Those of the 10 commandments which are actually moral in nature can be boiled down to that simple creedo. Of course the starting commandments about only worshiping a specific God and keeping a certain day as the sabath are not moral in nature, they're religious. It's important to understand that distinction; another reason not to follow the "the Bible says it so you should do it" philosophy.

 I oversimplified my answer. In addition to that point is the fact that not everything presented in the Bible is moral, as Matthew just pointed out. Feindslayer would like us to simply say "the Bible says it, so it's right." My point was that the Bible isn't right automatically. The bits that it got right it got right by adopting sound morals established external to the Bible, and it's gotten plenty wrong all on its own. Simply put the inclusion or exclusion of something in the Bible should really have no bearing on it's adoption as a moral standard. Just because it's written in a book, any book, does not make it correct. If you find some moral code that's repeated in the Bible and you think that's spiffy, then good for you. But if someone asks if something is moral and you say "Well, according to the Bible..." then you're telling them nothing really useful. Unless every line in the Bible which says "Do X" is correct, and we all know that's not the case, then citing the Bible as a definite authority isn't valid.
